bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, July 26, 1952

div1.p: Hench sends Nogueira the data on persons associated in various ways with the work of the U.S. Army Yellow Fever Board. He inquires whether a date has been set for the dedication of Camp Lazear. Hench suggests names of people who should be invited. Hench discusses the socio-political ramifications surrounding the naming of the site.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, July 26, 1952
div1.opener:
7 . 8
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
July 26, 1952
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
Marti 219, Marianao
Habana, Cuba
My dear Pedro:
div1.p:
At last I am able to send you the data on the persons associated in various ways
with the work of the U. S. Army Yellow Fever Board. In order to give you as
much information as possible I have made the list quite complete and inclusive.
To do so I have had to spend considerable time going over books, my voluminous
files, etc. But I'm glad I did so, as your request forced me to check and re-
check data so as to have names correct for perpetuation in bronze. In doing
so I uncovered even more errors than I had noted before.

I do not know what policy (regarding the selection of names to be honored) you
and your colleagues have adopted, whether you are going to honor only those
who actually worked at Camp Lazear (plus, of course, Finlay, Delgado and Lazear)
or whether you are going to be more inclusive and memorialize more broadly the
“Conquest of Yellow Fever”.

I will send a copy of the enclosed data to General Truby, perhaps also to Mr.
Hanberry (volunteer). I'm not sure that Dr. Cooke's health would permit him to
review my data; his memory is poor. But I think General Truby and Mr. Hanberry
may help us.

Incidentally the U.S. Army “Yellow Fever Board” was not an official designation
even though it is often called that, or the “Yellow Fever Commission”. All
sorts of “Boards of Officers” are created by military order; some are more or
less permanent; others have only a temporary job to do. The wording used to
create all such boards is customarily the same: “A board of officers, consist-
ing of.........., is appointed for the purpose of........”. The order creat-
ing the so-called “Yellow Fever Board” was no exception; according to the official
wording of the order which created it, it was just another “Board of officers”.

Despite this it does need some special distinction; therefore the “U.S. Army
Yellow Fever Board” is more appropriate than “Commission”.

Please let me know if you wish me to do anything more about finding the missing
middle names or middle initials of the persons named in my list. If we have time
I can write the Adjutant General, U.S. Army for their help. But it might take
two weeks or so to get the missing data.

Have you or your colleagues set a date for the dedication of “Camp Lazear”? I'd
certainly like to know when it is to be, and how I wish I could come but I fear
that I can't. If I did go I'd have to make a very quick trip. How I wish General
and Mrs. Truby could be there and how he would love to go. But an Army officer's
retirement pay does not allow much travel, and I don't suppose your Government
would deem it appropriate to bring to Havana any guests. But if you are consider-
ing American guests one thinks also of Walter Reed's son and daughter (both
living, and Doctor Lazear's son and daughter (both in California). Unfortunately
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
-2-
July 26, 1952
Doctor Carroll's son is not a very congenial man; indeed he is distinctly
antagonistic and I doubt if he would make a suitable guest. (Of course you
have right in Havana Agramonte's daughter.)

Pedro, if your “Dedication Committee” does want two or three American guests
it might be possible to interest the Surgeon General to send one or more re-
presentatives. Perhaps Generals Reed and Truby, although retired, could be
called back by the Surgeon General to act as his representatives, and be sent
at the Army's expense. I know General Armstrong fairly well and could sound
him out informally if you wish me to do so before you do anything official.

Do you have your own copy of Kelly's book on “Walter Reed and Yellow Fever”
or a copy of Mrs. Sternberg's “Life of General Sternberg” (Surgeon General,
U.S. Army who created the Yellow Fever Board, 1900)? If you do not have your
own copies and if you would like me to do so I'll try to find copies for you
and send them to you.

Thank you very much for asking the Air Force officers to take another series
of air views (tangential as well as perpendicular). But you will recall that
I was most anxious to be allowed either to borrow or to buy the films because
I want some enlargements of various special areas, e.g., the area around the
Finca San Jose, that around the false camp, etc. I want to make slides as well
as prints of various sizes. That is why I was so anxious for them to lend me
the other ones they took. (And if they file them so casually that they can't
find them, or if they throw them away, I wonder if they wouldn't let me have
them. I can assure you I will only use them for proper purposes as they would
approve.)

As stated in the enclosure I am still very hopeful that sometime soon you or
I can arrange to get complete microfilms of Doctor Finlay's “diaries”. I think
somebody told me that there was now a microfilm camera somewhere in Havana.
Perhaps Doctor Presno would permit me to have three copies made at my expense:
one for him, one for you and one for me. Do you think we could get it done?
Do you want me to make a formal request to him?

I do hope you received my letter of July 7 with its personal “addendum” about
the re-naming (?) of Camp Lazear or at least about the erroneous designation
“caseta de Finlay”. Perhaps you have quietly done something about this.

I hope very much that you have. It would be very unfortunate if that news-
paper error were allowed to continue without correction by the Cuban Govern-
ment. The very purpose of the memorial project at Camp Lazear would be de-
feated or perverted. There are many fine memorials to Finlay in Havana. That
is as it should be! But this was to be a joint memorial. I know very well
of your own attitude, which is shared by such men as Doctor Ramos and others
who wish to honor both Doctor Finlay and the “Americans”. As the time for the
dedication approaches I'm getting somewhat more disturbed lest an unfortunate
misunderstanding spoil our purposes.

If you have discussed this matter tactfully with your colleagues and if any of
them is inclined to dismiss the erroneous designation as “unimportant” and not
inclined to help you correct it (as I know you intended to do last January),
Pedro, I beg of you to discuss it with them again.

Make them understand that there are many important Cubans as well as Americans
who now know considerable about Camp Lazear and “Building Number One”, far too
many for the newspapers to ignore. These include several Cuban physicians,
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
-3-
July 26, 1952
one or two Cuban writers and others who have (of their own volition) corresponded
with me about Camp Lazear. Also many prominent American business, social and
official persons in Havana know the significance of “Camp Lazear”. I refer
to the Embassy group, to the military attache and to other Americans also cer-
tain Havana correspondents for American newspapers. Through the past twelve
years as I have visited Havana I have made many contacts as I sought help to
uncover this or that data. I have kept in correspondence with many of them.

All of these people would be simply delighted to join with their Cuban friends
in dedicating a joint memorial, truly a Cuban-American Memorial to Finlay, Del-
gado and the “Americans” who worked at Camp Lazear. But they would feel affronted
and distressed if the unfortunate error about which I wrote you were to be per-
petuated or given the direct or tacit approval of either the Cuban Government
or the civil administration of Marianao. (You recall that Sydney Howard wrote
a popular play “Yellow Jack” with scenes laid at Camp Lazear; it was made into
a movie. Also Paul de Kruif has written much about the Camp Lazear episode.
Reader's Digest also often has something about the yellow fever story. I fear
that some of these people, professional writers, might be disturbed if Reed's
famous little “Building Number One” were improperly designated.)

Please write me and allay my concern. Is there anything you would like me to do?
If you want me to write “officially” or confidentially to anyone I will do so
at once. But I hope to go away on a little vacation after the middle of August
so please write me soon.
div1.closer:
Always your friend, Dr. P. S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota PSH:dsl
